abstract: Computer chip scientists say they may have to seek new paradigm as they reach limits of Moore's Law, principle that number of components that fit on single silicon chip can reliably be doubled; law has long been defining principle in industry; scientists say they may need to replace silicon with new material, or find new design methods, if progress is to continue.
lead_paragraph: Unsure how long chip memory can reliably be doubled, an engineering group plans to create a new forecasting system for semiconductor innovation.

headline.main: Moore’s Law Running Out of Room, Tech Looks for a Successor
headline.print_headline: No More Room to Shrink

snippet: Unsure how long chip memory can reliably be doubled, an engineering group plans to create a new forecasting system for semiconductor innovation....

abstract: Chobani yogurt company founder Hamdi Ulukaya is target of racist attacks on social media and conspiratorial articles on websites for being outspoken advocate for refugees; Turkish immigrant employs more than 300 refugees in his factories and has launched foundation to help migrants, inspiring other companies to help; civil rights advocates believe Ulukaya is being singled out because he is immigrant himself and his actions counter anti-immigration narrative.
lead_paragraph: Hamdi Ulukaya employs resettled refugees at his yogurt factories. Now he’s being targeted on social media and by right-wing websites.

headline.main: For Helping Immigrants, Chobani’s Founder Draws Threats
headline.print_headline: For Standing Up, Scorn

snippet: Hamdi Ulukaya employs resettled refugees at his yogurt factories. Now he’s being targeted on social media and by right-wing websites....

abstract: Oracle president for product development Thomas Kurian plays key role in tech giant’s late dive into cloud computing; Kurian oversees estimated $15 billion project to create network of 21 data centers, part of company's effort to stem loss of customers to Google, Amazon and other cloud-computing businesses.
lead_paragraph: The business software omnivore is playing catch-up in one of the hotter fields of tech. Its NetSuite purchase is its latest thrust in that direction.

headline.main: For Oracle, Money’s Not the Problem. It’s Coping With the Cloud.
headline.print_headline: Navigating the Cloud

abstract: Tribune Publishing chairman Michael W Ferro Jr contends his wide-ranging plans to reshape company will greatly increase its worth, making unsolicited bid by Gannett less likely; among biggest changes, Ferro is putting his closest associates on company's board and is renaming company to all-lower-case tronc, shortened version of Tribune online content.

byline.original: By LESLIE PICKER and SYDNEY EMBER

lead_paragraph: Michael W. Ferro Jr. is changing the newspaper conglomerate’s name and moving its stock listing to the Nasdaq hoping to make it seem more like a start-up.

abstract: US Chamber of Commerce chief executive Thomas J Donohue expresses disdain for Donald J Trump’s economic policies following threats by Trump to rip up trade accords, put tariffs on Chinese goods and start a trade war; acrimonious relationship with presumptive nominee is historic change for  pro-business organization whose goals usually line up with Republican establishment.
lead_paragraph: Differences over trade policies have led to an acrimonious relationship between the business association and the presumptive Republican nominee.

abstract: Apple, previously spared resistance from China over its products and market share, is now facing regulatory headwinds from country that could limit expansion; China has shut down iBooks Store and iTunes Movies services in country; company has looked to China as its iPhone sales weaken in United States.

byline.original: By PAUL MOZUR and JANE PERLEZ

lead_paragraph: The iBooks Store and iTunes Movies were closed six months after they began in China, which had been more welcoming of Apple than other tech companies.

abstract: Foxconn factory in Zhengzhou, China, which can produce 500,000 iPhones per day, receives heavy subsidies and other perks from Chinese government; opaque arrangement drives local economic growth and enables Apple's significant profits; increasingly contentious relationship between United States and China, exacerbated by Pres-elect Donald J Trump's trade proposals, could disrupt vast, lucrative system (Series: China Rules).

byline.contributor: Sui-Lee Wee contributed reporting from Zhengzhou, China. Zhang Ruoyao and Zhang Tiantian contributed research.

lead_paragraph: A hidden bounty of benefits for Foxconn’s plant in Zhengzhou, the world’s biggest iPhone factory, is central to the production of Apple’s most profitable product.

abstract: Shanghai Disney Resort is set to open in China, reflecting deal that opened coveted market to American brand following significant concessions to Communist government; history of negotiations points to growing willingness of many multinational companies to cooperate with control-focused Chinese state in order to gain access to world's second-largest economy (Series: China Rules).

byline.original: By DAVID BARBOZA and BROOKS BARNES

lead_paragraph: Plans for the $5.5 billion Shanghai Disney Resort, which opens Thursday, were in limbo until Disney dialed back its demands to the Communist Party.

headline.main: How China Won the Keys to Disney’s Magic Kingdom
headline.print_headline: Seeing Its Tomorrowland, Disney Courted China
